headline: Old-Fashioned Lemonade
description: A classic lemonade recipe to make all summer long, or anytime life gives you lemons! Just three ingredients needed for this crowd-pleasing pitcher.

video.description: This video will show you how to make Old-Fashioned Lemonade - the perfect cold drink for a hot summer day. Set aside the powder mix, this classic summertime recipe uses freshly squeezed lemons and sugar to create the perfect blend of sweet and tart.
video.name: Old-Fashioned Lemonade Recipe

name: Old-Fashioned Lemonade
recipeIngredient: 6 cups water, or more as needed

recipeInstructions.text: Juice lemons; you should have 1 cup juice.
Combine juice, sugar, and water in a 1/2-gallon pitcher. Stir until sugar dissolves. Taste and add more water if desired.

I did a half batch of this for a nice drink with a lunch at home and it was glorious. I hand squeezed the lemons with a simple juicer, running them in the microwave for thirty seconds (making sure to turn them occasionally) and squeezing lightly before cutting them to juice them. I also boiled one cup of the water to dissolve the sugar into. (Since I was halving it, it was a half cup of sugar into one cup of water. I'd suggest anyone else doing this to dissolve the sugar in twice as much water, so one cup of sugar in two cups, etc.) Used ice cubes to chill the lemonade. Maybe it was a little strong as I didn't measure the resulting juice, so maybe I had some exceptionally juicy lemons, but I liked it.

I think you mean to say a Half Gallon container. A gallon is 16 cups: a half gallon is 8 cups. 1 cup sugar and 1 cup lemon juice plus 6 cups of water will be just over 7 cups, leaving around a cup for ice, and fit very nicely in a half gallon. I made it in a gallon pitcher, which was very difficult to find and buy, and it looked so empty I thought you must mean to add a half gallon of ice, but the lemonade got very waterey and weak. Next time I made it in a half gallon pitcher, which most pitchers are so it was easy to find one, and just poured it straight over a glass of ice and it was great! I think you made a mistake telling us to make it in a gallon container and you should change the instruction to making it in a half gallon container.
